name: Correlation Analysis (Pearson)
description: Measures the linear relationship between two continuous variables. The result is a correlation coefficient between -1 (perfect negative correlation) and +1 (perfect positive correlation). A value near 0 indicates no linear correlation.
data_requirements: Requires at least two numerical (integer or float) columns.
use_cases: Identifying relationships between variables, such as 'does advertising spend correlate with sales?'
Feature selection in machine learning to remove highly correlated features.

name: Independent Samples T-Test
description: Compares the means of two independent groups to determine whether there is a statistically significant difference between them.
data_requirements: Requires one numerical column (the dependent variable) and one categorical column with exactly two distinct groups (the independent variable).
use_cases: A/B testing: Comparing the conversion rates of two different website designs.
Medical trials: Comparing the effectiveness of a drug versus a placebo.
Comparing the average salary of two different departments.

name: ANOVA (Analysis of Variance)
description: Compares the means of three or more independent groups to determine if at least one group mean is different from the others.
data_requirements: Requires one numerical column (the dependent variable) and one categorical column with three or more distinct groups (the independent variable).
use_cases: Comparing the effectiveness of three or more different teaching methods on student scores.
Determining if different manufacturing processes result in different product strengths.

name: Time Series Forecasting (e.g., ARIMA, Prophet)
description: Predicts future values based on previously observed values. It involves analyzing time-stamped data to identify patterns like trends, seasonality, and cycles.
data_requirements: Requires at least one datetime or date column and one numerical column whose values are recorded over time.
use_cases: Forecasting stock prices or sales revenue.
Predicting website traffic or electricity demand.

name: Categorical Distribution Analysis (Chi-Squared Test)
description: Analyzes the frequency distribution of categorical variables. Can be used to test if the observed distribution of a categorical variable differs from an expected distribution, or to test for independence between two categorical variables.
data_requirements: Requires one or two categorical (object or string) columns.
use_cases: Determining if there is a relationship between a customer's region and their product preference.
Analyzing survey responses to see if demographic groups have different opinions.
